<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Operating Revenues</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $45 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to increases of $56 million in generation revenues and $19 million in trading
  revenues, partially offset by a decrease of $30 million in gas supply revenues.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $357 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was due to increases of $278 million in generation revenues, $47 million in gas supply
  revenues and $32 million in trading revenues.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Generation</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The increase of $56 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to an increase of $68 million due to higher sales volumes in the various
  power pools, supported by improved nuclear operations and the commencement of the commercial operations of Linden in May 2006 and BEC in July 2005 and an increase of $56 million due to higher
  prices under the BGS contracts. The increases were partially offset by a reduction in load being served under the BGS contracts, $32 million of unrealized losses on asset-backed electric forward contracts
  and a decrease of $30 million due to the maturity of certain wholesale contracts in early 2006.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The increase of $278 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to $307 million of higher sales volumes in the various power
  pools, supported by improved nuclear operations and the commencement of the commercial operations of Linden and BEC and $59 million of higher prices under the BGS contracts. The increases were
  partially offset by a reduction in load being served under the BGS contracts, $63 million of unrealized losses on asset-backed electric forward contracts and a decrease of $37 million due to the maturity of
  certain wholesale contracts in early 2006 and 2005.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">67</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Gas Supply</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Gas supply revenues decreased $30 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, principally due to a decrease of $32 million from lower gas prices and
  reduced demand under the BGSS contract, resulting from customer conservation and warmer winter weather in 2006 and a decrease of $16 million in prices charged to other gas distributors for gas and
  pipeline capacity. These decreases were partially offset by $22 million of gains on derivative forward contracts.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $47 million increase in gas supply revenues for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to increases of $304 million in gas prices
  under the BGSS contract and $13 million in sales prices charged to other gas distributors for gas and pipeline capacity. Increased prices were partially offset by lower demand of $207 million under the
  BGSS contract in 2006 and a reduction of $68 million in sales volume to other gas distributors.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Trading</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $19 million increase in trading revenues for the quarter ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to higher realized gains related to electric contracts.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $32 million increase in trading revenues for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was principally due to higher realized and unrealized gains related
  to electric contracts and emissions credits.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Operating Expenses</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Energy Costs</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Energy Costs represent the cost of generation, which includes fuel purchases for generation as well as purchased energy in the market, and gas purchases to meet Power&rsquo;s obligation under its BGSS
  contract with PSE&amp;G.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Energy Costs decreased approximately $153 million for the quarter ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily due to lower generation costs, reflecting decreases of
  $90 million resulting from lower pool prices and a reduction in the volume of purchases from the various power pools due to lower load obligations and $20 million due to favorable pricing of fuel-related
  asset-backed transactions in 2006. In addition, fossil fuel expenses decreased $19 million due to lower load obligations and gas purchased to satisfy Power&rsquo;s BGSS obligations decreased $39 million due to
  lower prices. These decreases were partially offset by an increase of $16 million in various congestion and transmission costs.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $51 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to increases of $91 million from higher prices on a reduced volume
  of gas purchased to satisfy Power&rsquo;s BGSS obligations and $85 million from a higher volume of fossil fuel purchases used to support generation by Linden and BEC. These increases were partially offset by a
  decrease of $127 million, representing lower pool prices and a reduction in the volume of purchases from the various power pools.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Operation and Maintenance</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Operation and Maintenance expense decreased $1 million and increased $36 million for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005.
  The increase of $36 million was principally due to higher maintenance costs of $50 million related to certain of the fossil plants and a scheduled outage at a nuclear unit partially offset by the absence of a
  $14&nbsp;million restructuring charge incurred in 2005 related to Nuclear&rsquo;s workforce realignment plan.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">68</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Depreciation and Amortization</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $7 million and $20 million increases for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, was primarily due to Linden and BEC being
  placed into service.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Other Income and Deductions</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Other Income and Deductions decreased $50 million and $49 million for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily due to
  decreased net realized income related to the NDT Funds of $37&nbsp;million and $39 million for the quarter and year-to-date periods, respectively. Also contributing to the decrease for the quarter and nine
  months was an environmental reserve of approximately $15&nbsp;million recorded in the third quarter of 2006 for potential penalties and other costs related to ongoing negotiations for an alternate pollution
  reduction plan for Power&rsquo;s Hudson unit. These decreases were partially offset by higher interest income of $2 million and $6 million for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2006, respectively,
  as compared to the same period in 2005.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Interest Expense</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Interest Expense increased $15 million and $45 million for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, due primarily to lower
  capitalized interest costs in 2006 related to commencement of operations of the BEC and Linden facilities.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Income Taxes</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Income Taxes increased $54 million for the quarter and $65 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same periods in 2005, primarily due to higher pre-tax income.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Loss from Discontinued Operations, including Loss on Disposal, net of tax</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On May 27, 2005, Power reached an agreement to sell its Waterford generation facility for approximately $220 million and recognized a loss on disposal of approximately $177 million for the initial
  write-down of its carrying amount of Waterford to its fair value less cost to sell. On September&nbsp;28, 2005, Power completed the sale of Waterford and recognized an additional loss of $1 million. The proceeds,
  together with anticipated reduction in tax liability, were approximately $320&nbsp;million, which was used to retire debt at Power. The loss from the discontinued operating results of Waterford was $6&nbsp;million and
  $19 million for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2005, respectively. See Note 3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes for additional information.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">69</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>

    <TD align="right"><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.1mm; ">
       151</FONT></TD>
    <TD colspan="2">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></td>
    <TD><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.1mm; ">
      $</FONT></TD>
    <td><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></td>

<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Operating Revenues</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $67 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to higher revenues at Global of $78 million, which was primarily related
  to a $60 million increase at TIE. The increase at TIE included an increase of $63 million related to unrealized gains on forward contracts and $13 million due to increased output available for sale, partially
  offset by lower prices of $16 million driven by lower gas costs. Also included in the increase at Global were a $9 million increase due to the consolidation of Prisma which began in May 2006 when Global
  increased its ownership interest from 50% to 85% and an $8 million increase at Sociedad Austral de Electricidad S.A. (SAESA) in Chile due to increased tariff prices and volume, offset by a decrease of
  revenues at Resources of $12 million primarily due to $8 million of lower lease income.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $163 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to higher revenues at Global of $171 million, which was primarily
  related to a $163 million increase at TIE. The increase at TIE included increases of $115 million related to unrealized gains on forward contracts, $27 million due to increased output available for sale and
  $21&nbsp;million due to price increases. Also contributing to the increase at Global was a $48 million increase at SAESA due to increased tariffs and volume and a $17 million increase due to the consolidation of
  Prisma, partially offset by decreased revenues due to the absence of $37 million of income received in 2005 from withdrawal from Eagle Point Cogeneration Partnership (EPCP) and a $23 million decrease
  related to the deconsolidation of Dhofar Power. The deconsolidation of Dhofar Power resulted from Global&rsquo;s sale of a 35% interest in Dhofar Power through a public offering on the Omani Stock
  Exchange in April 2005, reducing its ownership interest to 46% and thus accounting for the investment under the equity method of accounting following the sale. The increase at Global was partially offset
  by an $8 million decrease in revenues at Resources primarily due to the reduction in leveraged lease income of $25&nbsp;million, offset by the $21 million write-off of its leveraged lease investment with United
  Airlines in 2005.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Operating Expenses</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Energy Costs</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The
  $11 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2006, as compared to
  the same period in 2005, was primarily due to increases of $4 million at SAESA
  due to increased volume and increases in energy costs due to higher spot prices,
  $3 million due to the consolidation of Prisma and $3 million at TIE resulting
  from an increase of $13 million in gas purchases offset primarily by lower fuel
  costs of $10 million.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $99 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to a $64 million increase at TIE resulting mainly from an increase in</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">70</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">unrealized losses on gas purchases of $51 million coupled with a $13 million increase in fuel purchases. Also contributing to the increase was a $33 million increase at SAESA due to increased volume and
  increases in energy costs due to higher spot prices and a $6 million increase due to the consolidation of Prisma. These increases were partially offset by a $5 million decrease related to the deconsolidation of
  Dhofar Power.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Operation and Maintenance</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The
  $8 million increase for the quarter ended September 30, 2006, as compared to
  the same period in 2005, was primarily due to a $7 million increase at SAESA
  resulting from repairs of a gas turbine for which it has filed a claim for insurance
  recovery.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Write-down of Project Investments</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $263 million increase in the write-down of project investments relates to Global&rsquo;s sale of its 32% indirect ownership interest in RGE to its partner. See Note 3. Discontinued Operations,
  Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Income from Equity Method Investments</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $3 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to the consolidation of Prisma generating an increase in earnings of
  $5&nbsp;million and stronger results from Global&rsquo;s investments in Hawaii (Kalaeloa) and California (GWF) totaling $3 million, offset by a reduction of $5 million in the equity from investments in Latin America
  due to the sale of Global&rsquo;s 32% indirect interest in RGE.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Other Income and Deductions</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The
  $4 million decrease for the quarter ended September 30, 2006 compared to the
  same period in the prior year, was primarily due to a loss recorded on the extinguishment
  of debt, which was partially offset by higher interest income and lower losses
  in foreign currency transactions.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The
  $5 million increase for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared
  to the same period in 2005, was primarily due to an increase in interest income
  and lower losses in foreign currency transactions which was partially offset
  by the loss recorded on the extinguishment of debt.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Interest Expense</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $6 million and $17 million decreases for the quarter and nine months ended September 30, 2006, respectively, as compared to the same periods in 2005, was primarily due to a decrease in Energy
  Holdings&rsquo; debt outstanding.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Income Taxes</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The $7 million decrease for the quarter ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily attributable to a $9 million U.S. tax associated with repatriation of funds
  recorded in 2005. The $73 million decrease for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, was primarily attributable to a tax benefit resulting from Global&rsquo;s sale of
  its 32% indirect ownership interest in RGE.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Income from Discontinued Operations, including Gain on Disposal, net of tax</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In May 2006, Global completed the sale of its interest in two coal-fired plants in Poland, Elcho and Skawina. The sale resulted in an after-tax gain of $228 million. Income (Loss) from Discontinued
  Operations related to Elcho and Skawina for the quarters ended September 30, 2006 and 2005 was $0&nbsp;million and $9 million, respectively. Income (Loss) from Discontinued Operations related to Elcho and
  Skawina for the nine months ended September 30, 2006 and 2005 was $(1) million and $13 million,</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">71</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">respectively. See Note 3. Discontinued Operations, Dispositions and Acquisitions of the Notes for additional information.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=liquidity1>LIQUIDITY AND CAPITAL RESOURCES</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The following discussion of liquidity and capital resources is on a consolidated basis for PSEG, noting the uses and contributions of PSEG&rsquo;s three direct operating subsidiaries, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy
  Holdings.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Operating Cash Flows</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">For the nine months ended September 30, 2006, PSEG&rsquo;s operating cash flow increased approximately $541 million from $903 million to $1,444 million, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily
  due to net increases from its subsidiaries as discussed below.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s operating cash flow decreased approximately $41 million from $464 million to $423 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, primarily
  due to a decrease in customer deposits partially offset by higher over recovery of gas costs resulting from lower commodity prices in 2006.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power&rsquo;s operating cash flow increased approximately $644 million from $276 million to $920&nbsp;million for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as compared to the same period in 2005, due to
  decreases in accounts receivable and fuel inventory, largely resulting from decreased commodity prices.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Energy
  Holdings&rsquo; operating cash flow decreased approximately $80 million from
  $229 million to $149 million for the nine months ended September 30, 2006, as
  compared to the same period in 2005. The $80 million decrease is primarily due
  to the timing of net tax payments associated with the net gain on the sale of
  Elcho, Skawina and RGE during 2006 as well as higher distributions from partnerships
  during 2005 due to the withdrawal from EPCP. The proceeds from the Elcho, Skawina
  and RGE sales are included in Investing Activities on Energy Holdings&rsquo;
  Condensed Consolidated Statements of Cash Flows.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Common Stock Dividends</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Dividend payments on common stock for the quarters ended September 30, 2006 and 2005 were $0.57 and $0.56 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $144 million and $134 million,
  respectively. Dividend payments on common stock for the nine months ended September 30, 2006 and 2005 were $1.71 and $1.68 per share, respectively, and totaled approximately $430 million and
  $401&nbsp;million, respectively. Future dividends declared will be dependent upon PSEG&rsquo;s future earnings, cash flows, financial requirements, alternative investment opportunities and other factors. On
  October&nbsp;17, 2006, PSEG&rsquo;s Board of Directors approved a common stock dividend of $0.57 per share for the fourth quarter of 2006, reflecting an indicated annual dividend rate of $2.28 per share.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">72</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Short-Term Liquidity</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of September 30, 2006, PSEG and its subsidiaries had a total of approximately $3.7 billion of committed credit facilities with approximately $3.1 billion of available liquidity under these facilities. In
  addition, PSEG and PSE&amp;G have access to certain uncommitted credit facilities. Each of the facilities is restricted to availability and use to the specific companies as listed below.</FONT></P>

  <TR valign="top" bgcolor="#e5ffff">
    <TD>
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 3.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B> <font style="border-bottom:solid 0.50pt black;">PSEG:</font></B></FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3"><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <TD align="center"><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></TD>

    <TD colspan="6"><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <TD width="3"><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <TD align="center"><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <TD width="3"><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></TD>

<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">73</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG and PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG and PSE&amp;G believe sufficient liquidity exists to fund their short-term cash needs.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of September 30, 2006, Power had borrowed $68 million from PSEG in the form of an intercompany loan.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During the third quarter of 2006, Power&rsquo;s required margin postings decreased for sales contracts entered into in the normal course of business as commodity prices declined. The required margin
  postings will fluctuate based on volatility in commodity prices. Should commodity prices rise, additional margin calls may be necessary relative to existing power sales contracts. As Power&rsquo;s contract
  obligations are fulfilled, liquidity requirements are reduced. Power believes that it has sufficient liquidity to fund its short-term cash needs.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In addition, ER&amp;T maintains agreements that require Power, as its guarantor under performance guarantees, to satisfy certain creditworthiness standards. In the event of a deterioration of Power&rsquo;s credit
  rating to below investment grade, which represents at least a two level downgrade from its current ratings, many of these agreements allow the counterparty to demand that ER&amp;T provide performance
  assurance, generally in the form of a letter of credit or cash. Providing this support would increase Power&rsquo;s costs of doing business and could restrict the ability of ER&amp;T to manage and optimize Power&rsquo;s asset
  portfolio. Power believes it has sufficient liquidity to meet any required posting of collateral resulting from a credit rating downgrade. See Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities of the Notes for
  further information.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Energy Holdings and its subsidiaries had $102 million in cash, including $19 million invested offshore as of September 30, 2006. In addition, as of September 30, 2006, Energy Holdings had an
  outstanding demand loan receivable from PSEG of $374 million. See External Financings&#8212;Energy Holdings below for Energy Holdings&rsquo; additional use of its excess cash.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>External Financings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On September 1, 2006, PSEG began using treasury stock to settle the exercise of stock options. Prior to September 1, 2006, PSEG had purchased shares on the open market to meet the exercise of
  stock options. As of September 30, 2006, PSEG issued approximately 121,067 shares of its common treasury stock in connection with settling stock options for approximately $5 million.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During the nine months ended September 30, 2006, PSEG issued approximately 790,825 shares of its common stock under its Dividend Reinvestment Program and Employee Stock Purchase Program
  for approximately $51 million.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In February 2006, PSEG redeemed $154 million of its Subordinated Debentures underlying $150&nbsp;million of Enterprise Capital Trust II, Floating Rate Capital Securities and its common equity
  investment in the trust.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On June 23, 2006, PSE&amp;G repaid at maturity $174 million of its Floating Rate Series A First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On March 1, 2006, PSE&amp;G repaid at maturity $148 million of its 6.75% Series UU First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In September 2006, June 2006 and March 2006, PSE&amp;G Transition Funding LLC (Transition Funding) repaid approximately $41 million, $35 million and $36 million, respectively, of its transition bonds.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">74</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In June 2006, PSE&amp;G Transition Funding II LLC (Transition Funding II) repaid approximately $3&nbsp;million of its transition bonds.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In April 2006, Power repaid at maturity $500 million of its 6.875% Senior Notes.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In January 2006, Energy Holdings redeemed all $309 million of its 7.75% Senior Notes due in 2007.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On February 17, 2006, the maturity of the Odessa&#8209;Ector Power Partners, L.P. (Odessa) debt was extended to December 31, 2009. Interest on the debt is based on a spread (currently 2.25%) above
  LIBOR. On September 29, 2006, an interest rate swap took effect which converts the floating LIBOR interest rate on approximately 80% of Odessa&rsquo;s debt to a fixed rate of 5.4275% through December 31,
  2009.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On October 23, 2006, Energy Holdings redeemed $300 million of its $507 million outstanding 8.625% Senior Notes due in 2008. Additionally, on September 20, 2006, Energy Holdings made a cash
  distribution to PSEG of $425 million in the form of a return of capital.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During
  the first nine months of 2006, Energy Holdings repaid approximately $37 million
  of non-recourse debt, of which $30 million was paid by Global, primarily related
  to SAESA and TIE, $5&nbsp;million by Resources and $2 million by EGDC.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Contractual Obligations</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of September 30, 2006, contractual cash obligations and other commercial commitments have not changed significantly from those reported in the Capital Requirements section of Management&rsquo;s
  Discussion and Analysis included in the 2005 Annual Report on Form 10K, except for the debt redemptions discussed above in External Financings.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Debt Covenants</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG&rsquo;s, PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s, Power&rsquo;s and Energy Holdings&rsquo; respective credit agreements generally contain customary provisions under which the lenders can refuse to advance loans in the event of a material
  adverse change in the borrower&rsquo;s business or financial condition.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As explained in more detail below, these credit agreements may also contain maximum debt to equity ratios, minimum cash flow tests and other restrictive covenants and conditions to borrowing.
  Compliance with applicable financial covenants will depend upon the respective future financial position, level of earnings and cash flows of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings, as to which no
  assurances can be given. The ratios presented below are for the benefit of the investors of the related securities to which the covenants apply. They are not intended as a financial performance or liquidity
  measure.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Financial covenants contained in PSEG&rsquo;s credit facilities include a ratio of debt (excluding non-recourse project financings, securitization debt and debt underlying preferred securities and including
  commercial paper and loans, certain letters of credit and similar instruments) to total capitalization (including preferred securities outstanding) covenant. This covenant requires that at the end of any
  quarterly financial period, such ratio not be more than 70.0%. As of September 30, 2006, PSEG&rsquo;s ratio of debt to capitalization (as defined above) was 52.8%.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">75</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Financial covenants contained in PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s credit facilities include a ratio of long-term debt (excluding securitization debt, long-term debt maturing within one year and short-term debt) to total
  capitalization covenant. This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial period, such ratio will not be more than 65.0%. As of September 30, 2006, PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s ratio of long-term debt to total
  capitalization (as defined above) was 45.3%.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">In addition, under its First and Refunding Mortgage (Mortgage), PSE&amp;G may issue new First and Refunding Mortgage Bonds against previous additions and improvements, provided that its ratio of
  earnings to fixed charges calculated in accordance with its Mortgage is at least 2 to 1, and/or against retired Mortgage Bonds. As of September 30, 2006, PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s Mortgage coverage ratio was 4.5 to 1 and the
  Mortgage would permit up to approximately $1.9 billion aggregate principal amount of new Mortgage Bonds to be issued against previous additions and improvements.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG and Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Financial covenants contained in the PSEG/Power joint and several credit facility include a ratio of debt to total capitalization for each specific borrower. This facility has a 70.0% debt to total
  capitalization covenant for PSEG (calculated as set forth above) and a 65.0% debt to total capitalization covenant for Power. The Power ratio is the same debt to total capitalization calculation as set forth
  above for PSEG except common equity is adjusted for the $986 million Basis Adjustment (see Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets). This covenant requires that at the end of any quarterly financial
  period, such ratio will not exceed 65.0%. As of September 30, 2006, Power&rsquo;s ratio of debt to total capitalization (as defined above) was 39.3%.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Energy Holdings&rsquo; revolving credit agreement has a covenant requiring the ratio of Earnings Before Interest, Taxes, Depreciation and Amortization (EBITDA) to fixed charges to be greater than or
  equal to 1.75. As of September 30, 2006, Energy Holdings&rsquo; coverage of this covenant was 3.94. Additionally, Energy Holdings must maintain a ratio of net debt (recourse debt offset by funds loaned to
  PSEG) to EBITDA of less than 5.25. As of September 30, 2006, Energy Holdings&rsquo; ratio under this covenant was 2.11. Energy Holdings is a co-borrower under this facility with Global and Resources, which
  are joint and several obligors. The terms of the agreement include a pledge of Energy Holdings&rsquo; membership interest in Global, restrictions on the use of proceeds related to material sales of assets and the
  satisfaction of certain financial covenants. Net cash proceeds from asset sales in excess of 5% of total assets of Energy Holdings during any 12-month period must be used to repay any outstanding amounts
  under the credit agreement. Net cash proceeds from asset sales during any 12-month period in excess of 10% of total assets must be retained by Energy Holdings or used to repay the debt of Energy
  Holdings, Global or Resources.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Credit Ratings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">On September 15, 2006, following the termination of the Merger Agreement, credit ratings remained unchanged as shown in the table below. Standard &amp; Poor&rsquo;s (S&amp;P) affirmed its &lsquo;BBB&rsquo; corporate credit
  rating for PSEG, Power, and PSE&amp;G. S&amp;P revised its outlook from watch developing to negative. Moody&rsquo;s Investors Service (Moody&rsquo;s) affirmed its credit ratings for PSEG and PSE&amp;G while revising the
  outlooks from stable to negative. The ratings and outlooks for Power and Energy Holdings were unchanged by Moody&rsquo;s. Fitch Ratings (Fitch) announced there would be no immediate impact on ratings
  and outlooks for PSEG and its subsidiaries. The agencies noted that the ratings below are predicated on continued improvement in financial metrics, specifically operating cash flows and ongoing
  deleveraging, as well as continued strong operating performance from Power&rsquo;s generating units and reasonable outcomes to PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s pending electric and gas rate cases.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">76</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">If the rating agencies lower or withdraw the credit ratings, such revisions may adversely affect the market price of PSEG&rsquo;s, PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s, Power&rsquo;s and Energy Holdings&rsquo; securities and serve to materially
  increase those companies&rsquo; cost of capital and limit their access to capital. Outlooks assigned to ratings are as follows: stable, negative (Neg) or positive (Pos). There is no assurance that the ratings will
  continue for any given period of time or that they will not be revised by the rating agencies, if, in their respective judgments, circumstances so warrant. Each rating given by an agency should be evaluated
  independently of the other agencies&rsquo; ratings. The ratings should not be construed as an indication to buy, hold or sell any security.</FONT></P>

    <TD>
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 10.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Outlook</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center"><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>
      Neg</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center"><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>
      Neg</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center"><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>
      Neg</B></FONT></TD>
  </TR>
  <TR valign="bottom">
    <TD>
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 10.5mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Senior Notes</FONT></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD align="center"><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      Ba3</FONT></TD>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 -8.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">&nbsp;</FONT></P>

<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Other Comprehensive Income (OCI)</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">For the nine months ended September 30, 2006, PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings had OCI of $576 million, $383 million and $192 million, respectively, due primarily to a reduction in the net
  unrealized losses on derivatives accounted for as hedges in accordance with SFAS 133 at Power and foreign currency translation adjustments at Energy Holdings.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During the nine months ended September 30, 2006, Power&rsquo;s Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss (OCL) decreased from $487 million to $104 million. The primary cause was a decrease of
  approximately $374 million related to energy and related contracts that qualify for hedge accounting that were entered into by Power in the normal course of business. During the nine months ended
  September 30, 2006, the decrease in gas and electric prices resulted in a reduction in unrealized losses on many of those contracts, which are recorded in OCL.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During the nine months ended September 30, 2006, Energy Holdings&rsquo; Accumulated Other Comprehensive (Loss) Income increased from $(110) million to $82 million. The primary cause was the
  realization of losses on Brazilian currency as a result of the sale of RGE.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">77</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=capital1>CAPITAL REQUIREMENTS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">It is expected that the majority of funding for capital requirements of PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings will come from their respective internally generated funds. The balance will be provided by the
  issuance of debt at the respective subsidiary or project level and, for PSE&amp;G and Power, equity contributions from PSEG. PSEG does not expect to contribute any additional equity to Energy Holdings.
  Projected construction and investment expenditures for PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are consistent with amounts disclosed in the Annual Reports on Form 10-K of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and
  Energy Holdings for the year ended December 31, 2005, with the exception of the indefinite postponement of the $30 million Electroandes hydro-expansion project at Energy Holdings which was planned
  for 2006 and 2007. For further information see Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Liabilities of the Notes.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSE&amp;G</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During the nine months ended September 30, 2006, PSE&amp;G made approximately $392 million of capital expenditures, primarily for reliability of transmission and distribution systems. The $392 million
  excludes approximately $26 million spent on cost of removal.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During the nine months ended September 30, 2006, Power made approximately $233 million of capital expenditures (excluding $83 million for nuclear fuel), primarily related to various projects at
  Fossil and Nuclear.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">During the nine months ended September 30, 2006, Energy Holdings incurred approximately $37&nbsp;million of capital expenditures, of which approximately $18 million related to SAESA.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=offbalance>OFF-BALANCE SHEET ARRANGEMENTS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">For
  a description of off-balance sheet arrangements, see Management&rsquo;s Discussion
  and Analysis in the 2005 Annual Report on Form 10-K. PSEG&rsquo;s pro rata share
  of the debt appearing on the consolidated financial statements of companies
  for which Global accounts under the equity method of investment was approximately
  $463 million as of September 30, 2006 as compared to $577 million as of December
  31, 2005. The decrease related principally to Energy Holdings&rsquo; sale of
  RGE in June 2006 and the change since May 2006 in Energy Holdings&rsquo; accounting
  for Prisma from the equity method to full consolidation. There has been no material
  change in the amount of Resources&rsquo; leveraged lease investments since December
  31, 2005. See Note 5. Commitments and Contingent Obligations of the Notes for
  an update of Power&rsquo;s guarantees related to certain of its energy trading
  activities and Energy Holdings&rsquo; guarantees of certain obligations of its
  subsidiaries or affiliates related to certain projects.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B><a name=accounting1>ACCOUNTING MATTERS</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">For information related to recent accounting matters, see Note 2. Recent Accounting Standards of the Notes.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">78</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=item3>ITEM 3. QUALITATIVE AND QUANTITATIVE DISCLOSURES<br>ABOUT MARKET RISK</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The market risk inherent in PSEG&rsquo;s, PSE&amp;G&rsquo;s, Power&rsquo;s and Energy Holdings&rsquo; market-risk sensitive instruments and positions is the potential loss arising from adverse changes in foreign currency
  exchange rates, commodity prices, equity security prices and interest rates as discussed in the Notes to Condensed Consolidated Financial Statements (Notes). It is the policy of each entity to use derivatives
  to manage risk consistent with its respective business plans and prudent practices. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have a Risk Management Committee (RMC) comprised of executive officers
  who utilize an independent risk oversight function to ensure compliance with corporate policies and prudent risk management practices.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Additionally, PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings are exposed to counterparty credit losses in the event of non-performance or non-payment. PSEG has a credit management process, which is
  used to assess, monitor and mitigate counterparty exposure for PSEG and its subsidiaries. In the event of non-performance or non-payment by a major counterparty, there may be a material adverse impact
  on PSEG and its subsidiaries&rsquo; financial condition, results of operations or net cash flows.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Except as discussed below, there were no material changes from the disclosures in the Annual Reports on Form 10-K of PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
  2005 or Quarterly Reports on Form 10-Q for the quarters ended March 31, 2006 and June 30, 2006.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Commodity Contracts</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The availability and price of energy commodities are subject to fluctuations from factors such as weather, environmental policies, changes in supply and demand, state and federal regulatory policies,
  market rules and other events. To reduce price risk caused by market fluctuations, Power enters into supply contracts and derivative contracts, including forwards, futures, swaps and options with approved
  counterparties. These contracts, in conjunction with demand obligations, help reduce risk and optimize the value of owned electric generation capacity.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Normal Operations and Hedging Activities</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power enters into physical contracts, as well as financial contracts, including forwards, futures, swaps and options designed to reduce risk associated with volatile commodity prices. Commodity price
  risk is associated with market price movements resulting from market generation demand, changes in fuel costs and various other factors.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Under SFAS No. 133, &ldquo;Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities&rdquo;, as amended (SFAS 133), changes in the fair value of qualifying cash flow hedge transactions are recorded in
  Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss (OCL), and gains and losses are recognized in earnings when the underlying transaction occurs. Changes in the fair value of derivative contracts that do not meet
  hedge criteria under SFAS 133 and the ineffective portion of hedge contracts are recognized in earnings currently. Additionally, changes in the fair value attributable to fair value hedges are similarly
  recognized in earnings.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Many non-trading contracts qualify for the normal purchases and normal sales exemption under SFAS 133 and are accounted for upon settlement.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Trading</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power maintains a strategy of entering into trading positions to optimize the value of its portfolio of generation assets, gas supply contracts and its electric and gas supply obligations. Power engages in
  physical and financial transactions in the electricity wholesale markets and executes an overall risk management strategy to mitigate the effects of adverse movements in the fuel and electricity markets. In
  addition, Power has non-asset based trading activities, which have significantly decreased over the</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">79</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">past year. These contracts also involve financial transactions including swaps, options and futures. These activities are marked to market in accordance with SFAS 133 with gains and losses recognized in
  earnings.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Value-at-Risk (VaR) Models</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power uses VaR models to assess the market risk of its commodity businesses. The portfolio VaR model for Power includes its owned generation and physical contracts, as well as fixed price sales
  requirements, load requirements and financial derivative instruments. VaR represents the potential gains or losses, under normal market conditions, for instruments or portfolios due to changes in market
  factors, for a specified time period and confidence level. Power estimates VaR across its commodity businesses.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Power manages its exposure at the portfolio level. Its portfolio consists of owned generation, load-serving contracts (both gas and electric), fuel supply contracts and energy derivatives designed to
  manage the risk around generation and load. While Power manages its risk at the portfolio level, it also monitors separately the risk of its trading activities and its hedges. Non-trading mark-to-market
  (MTM) VaR consists of MTM derivatives that are economic hedges, some of which qualify for hedge accounting. The MTM derivatives that are not hedges are included in the trading VaR.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The VaR models used by Power are variance/covariance models adjusted for the delta of positions with a 95% one-tailed confidence level and a one-day holding period for the MTM trading and non-
  trading activities and a 95% one-tailed confidence level with a one-week holding period for the portfolio VaR. The models assume no new positions throughout the holding periods, whereas Power actively
  manages its portfolio.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">As of September 30, 2006 and December 31, 2005, trading VaR was less than $1 million.</FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%;" >
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD style="width:74.48%;"><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <TD style="width:10.33%;" colspan="6"><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <TD style="width:2.63%"><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></TD>
    <TD style="width:9.92%;" colspan="6"><font style="font-size:0.6mm;">&nbsp;</font></TD>
  </TR>

  <TR valign="bottom">
    <TD align="center">
    <P style="text-indent:-3.5mm; margin:0 0 0 3.5mm; "><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></P></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      Trading VaR</B></FONT></TD>
    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="6" align="center" style="border-bottom:solid 0.2mm Black; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      Non-Trading<br>MTM VaR</B></FONT></TD>
  </TR>

  <TR valign="bottom">

    <TD colspan="13" align="center"><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.1mm; "><B>
      (Millions)</B></FONT></TD>

    <TD>

    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>

    <td><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></td>

    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></td>

<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>Other Supplemental Information Regarding Market Risk</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The following presentation of the activities of Power is included to address the recommended disclosures by the energy industry&rsquo;s Committee of Chief Risk Officers. For additional information, see
  Note 6. Risk Management of the Notes.</FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The following table describes the drivers of Power&rsquo;s energy trading and marketing activities and Operating Revenues included in its Condensed Consolidated Statement of Operations for the quarter
  and nine months ended September 30, 2006. Normal operations and hedging activities represent the marketing of electricity available from Power&rsquo;s owned or contracted generation sold into the wholesale
  market. As the information in this table highlights, MTM activities represent a small portion of the total Operating Revenues for Power. Activities accounted for under the accrual method, including normal
  purchases and sales, account for the majority of the revenue. The MTM activities reported here are those relating to changes in fair value due to external movement in prices.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">80</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>

    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="17"><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">
      Includes derivative contracts that Power enters into to hedge anticipated exposures related to its owned and contracted generation supply, all asset-backed transactions and hedging activities, but
      excludes owned and contracted generation assets.</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The following table indicates Power&rsquo;s energy trading assets and liabilities, as well as Power&rsquo;s hedging activity related to asset-backed transactions and derivative instruments that qualify for hedge
  accounting under SFAS 133, its amendments and related guidance. This table presents amounts segregated by portfolio which are then netted for those counterparties with whom Power has the right to
  offset and therefore, are not necessarily indicative of amounts presented on the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets since balances with many counterparties are subject to offset and are shown net on
  the Condensed Consolidated Balance Sheets regardless of the portfolio in which they are included.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">81</FONT></P>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">Wherever possible, fair values for these contracts were obtained from quoted market sources. For contracts where no quoted market exists, modeling techniques were employed using assumptions
  reflective of current market rates, yield curves and forward prices as applicable to interpolate certain prices. The effect of using such modeling techniques is not material to Power&rsquo;s financial results.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The following table identifies losses on cash flow hedges that are currently in OCL, a separate component of equity. Power uses forward sale and purchase contracts, swaps and firm transmission rights
  (FTRs) contracts to hedge forecasted energy sales from its generation stations and its contracted supply obligations. Power also enters into swaps, options and futures transactions to hedge the price of fuel
  to meet its fuel purchase requirements for generation. PSEG, Power and Energy Holdings are subject to the risk of fluctuating interest rates in the normal course of business. PSEG&rsquo;s policy is to manage
  interest rate risk through the use of fixed rate debt, floating rate debt and interest rate derivatives. The table also provides an estimate of the losses that are expected to be reclassified out of OCL and into
  earnings over the next 12 months.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Cash Flow Hedges Included in Accumulated Other Comprehensive Loss<br>As of September 30, 2006</B></FONT></P>
<table cellspacing="0" style="margin-left:0.00%;margin-right:0.00%;width:100.00%;" >

    <TD width="3">&nbsp;</TD>
    <td><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></td>

<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">82</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">
<PAGE>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Power</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B><I>Credit Risk</I></B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The following table provides information on Power&rsquo;s credit exposure, net of collateral, as of September 30, 2006. Credit exposure is defined as any positive results of netting accounts
  receivable/accounts payable and the forward value on open positions. It further delineates that exposure by the credit rating of the counterparties and provides guidance on the concentration of credit risk to
  individual counterparties and an indication of the maturity of a company&rsquo;s credit risk by credit rating of the counterparties.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:4.2mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Schedule of Credit Risk Exposure on Energy Contracts Net Assets<br>As of September 30, 2006</B></FONT></P>

<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 -8.7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">&nbsp;</FONT></P>
<TABLE cellspacing=0 cellpadding=0 style="margin-left:0.00pc;font-size:0.2mm;">

    <td><font style="font-size:0.2mm">&nbsp;</font></td>

      Counterparty is PSE&amp;G.</FONT>
    <P style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "></FONT></P></TD>
  </TR>

</TABLE>



<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">The net exposure listed above, in some cases, will not be the difference between the current exposure and the collateral held. A counterparty may have posted more collateral than the outstanding
  exposure, in which case there would not be exposure. As of September 30, 2006, Power had 129 active counterparties.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:6.3mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.5mm; "><B><a name=item4>ITEM 4. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES</a></B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:4.2mm; "><B>PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings</B></FONT></P>
<P style="margin:3.5mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Disclosure Controls and Procedures</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have established and maintain disclosure controls and procedures which are designed to provide reasonable assurance that information required to be
  disclosed is recorded, processed, summarized and reported within the time periods specified in the SEC&rsquo;s rules and forms and that material information relating to each company, including their respective
  consolidated subsidiaries, is accumulated and communicated to the respective company&rsquo;s management, including the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer of each company by others within
  those entities to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosure. PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings have established a disclosure committee which is made up of several key management
  employees and which reports directly to the Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each respective company. The committee monitors and evaluates the effectiveness of these disclosure
  controls and procedures. The Chief Financial Officer and Chief Executive Officer of each company have evaluated the effectiveness of the disclosure controls and procedures as of September 30, 2006 and,
  based on this evaluation, have concluded that the disclosure controls and procedures were effective in providing reasonable assurance during the period covered in these quarterly reports.</FONT></P>
<P style="margin:6.3mm 0 0 7mm; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; "><B>Internal Controls</B></FONT></P>
<P style="text-indent:7mm; margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">PSEG, PSE&amp;G, Power and Energy Holdings continually review their respective disclosure controls and procedures and make changes, as necessary, to ensure the quality of their financial reporting.
  However, there have been no changes in internal control over financial reporting that occurred during the third quarter of 2006 that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect,
  each registrant&rsquo;s internal control over financial reporting.</FONT></P>
<P align="center" style="margin:2.1mm 0 0; "><FONT style="font-family:Times New Roman, Times, serif; font-size:3.8mm; ">83</FONT></P>
<p><hr color=#000000 noshade></p>
<p style="page-break-before: always">

  2006 and June 30, 2006 is updated below.</FONT></P>
